review: Having been a long time Tivo user, I found using the Roku overall less than convenient as it could have been.  Its great in the respect of getting access to all sorts of both paid and free content, and the Streaming Stick is plenty responsive.  I found the interface cumbersome to locate my regular shows I watch through my subscribed channels as navigation varies slightly and requires multiple layers of image heavy menus.  I'd much rather have a more simple interface that showed me show names and episode titles in normal text form similar to that of the Tivo.  I watch my Roku on a 32" TV in bed at night, and trying to read/comprehend which show is which is difficult.  If you are going to ditch cable, I'd overlook these, but for now I think this will be relegated to the man-cave and my regular use TV's are sticking with Tivo.Additionally, the included remote does not act as a universal remote, so you'll need to keep your TV remote or get something like a Logitech Harmony Home universal remote.  You'll need one of the higher end (non-IR only) type remotes to work with the Roku, but I personally didn't think it was worth buying a remote that was more expensive than the Roku to get this feature, especially with the other shortcomings.  I guess Roku is playing to the cheapest common denominator fighting against the other streaming devices and forgot they are competing against more well established Cable/DVR products.  I was also in the market for a new TV shortly after getting the Roku Streaming Stick, so I thought buying a "Roku Ready" TV that included a remote with Roku functions would help with this as well, but alas this feature only works with the Roku Streaming Stick MHL version, not the HDMI version.  The MHL version is slightly more expensive, but in hindsight would have been much more preferred than going to expensive fancy universal remote route.
